conclusion: Analyze the motion of the charged particle in the magnetic field and its interaction with the insulating plate.
The particle is injected from point c with velocity v0 at an angle of 45° to MN.
The velocity components are v0x = v0 / √2 and v0y = v0 / √2.
The magnetic field B exerts a force on the particle, causing it to move in a circular path.
The radius r of the circular path is given by r = mv / qB.
The particle's velocity perpendicular to the magnetic field is v0x, which is responsible for the circular motion.
When the particle collides with the insulating plate ab, its horizontal velocity component vx reverses direction but maintains its magnitude.
The vertical component vy remains unchanged.
The particle starts at point c and moves towards the insulating plate.
After collision, the horizontal component of velocity reverses, causing the particle to move back towards the left side of MN.
The particle exits the magnetic field at point f, which is 2d from c.
The particle travels a distance of 2d horizontally from c to f.
The time t taken to travel this distance is t = 2d√2 / v0.
During this time, the particle completes half a circle (from c to the plate and back to f).
The time for half a circle is T/2, where T is the period of the circular motion.
The period T is given by T = 2πr / v0x = 2πm√2 / qB.
Equating the time for half a circle to the time calculated gives πm√2 / qB = 2d√2 / v0.
Solving for B gives B = πmv0 / 2qd.
The magnitude of the magnetic induction B is πmv0 / 2qd.
